awd_titl_txt: LSAMP Pre-Alliance Planning: C6: California Central Coast Community College Collaborative
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines to diversify the STEM workforce.  Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy.  Allan Hancock College (AHC), Cuesta College (CC) and Santa Barbara City College (SBCC) - the three community colleges that serve Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo Counties - will collaborate in a pre-alliance planning project (C6: California Central Coast Community College Collaborative) to develop a full Bridge to the Baccalaureate (B2B) LSAMP Alliance proposal.  The planning project will 1) convene faculty, staff and administrators from the colleges to share challenges and best practices, as well as goals to support URM student success; 2) analyze institutional retention and success data to identify equity gaps and bottleneck courses; 3) conduct student surveys and focus groups to drill down into specific obstacles and challenges faced by underrepresented minority students; 4) perform literature reviews to learn best practices; and 5) visit an existing B2B LSAMP project, and California State University and University of California LSAMP sites.  To generate a successful and sustainable full proposal, the core team of AHC, CC and SBCC will consolidate data and information from these various inputs.  The full alliance intends to provide common but flexible support programs that allow member colleges to work together in increasing the quantity and quality of transfer-ready URM STEM students.  Thus, the fundamental goal of C6 is to ensure a sufficient pool of prepared STEM students that reflects the diverse nature of our population as well as diversification of the STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: ALLAN HANCOCK JOINT COMMUNITY COLLEGE DISTRICT

por.por_cntn:
Louis Stokes Pre-Alliance Planning Project:

C6: California Central Coast Community College Collaborative

NSF Award No. 1817508

Eight California community colleges were supported by a National Science Foundation Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (NSF LSAMP) Pre-Alliance planning grant to create the California Central Coast Community College Collaborative (C6). The C6 Pre-Alliance project allowed the partner colleges to thoughtfully plan and develop collaborative effort and submit a LSAMP Bridge to the Baccalaureate (B2B) proposal which focuses on supporting underrepresented minority (URM) STEM students.

The goals of the C6 Pre-Alliance planning grant included:

  • Bringing together faculty, staff, and administration of three community colleges in Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo Counties, and expanding that alliance to include neighboring community colleges, south from Ventura County northward to Santa Cruz County.
  • Assessing URM student needs via student surveys
  • Connecting and consulting with the University of California (UC) LSAMP Alliance, the California State University (CSU) LSAMP Alliance, other LSAMP and existing STEM support programs to strengthen cooperation and articulation, as well as to investigate possible joint activities to facilitate student transfer and transition
  • Conducting a literature review, sharing existing support frame works across institutions, attending conferences, and visiting successful LSAMP programs in the state and nation to learn best practices
  • Coordinating discussions across campus institutional research departments that identify transfer pathway barriers
  • Writing and submitting a full LSAMP grant proposal at the end of the planning period

An initial kick-off meeting was attended by over 30 faculty, staff and administrators from ten community colleges (eventually eight colleges were able to participate in the project). COVID would soon make in-person meetings impossible, but Zoom was leveraged, allowing the C6 alliance members to meet monthly during the research and development stages of the proposal, and bi-weekly during the writing stages. The more-frequent Zoom meetings enabled the C6 network to develop stronger ties than traditionally would have been the case. The principal investigator team was able to attend in-person national LSAMP conferences at the beginning and end of the project, which helped C6 learn from active LSAMP alliances and the NSF LSAMP staff. The alliance colleges also learned successful practices from each other, as well as utilized the Aspen Institutes Essential Transfer Practices framework to reflect on URM STEM student support at each of their institutions, both of which heavily informed the overall C6 project.

The ultimate product of the pre-alliance planning grant - a LSAMP B2B proposal - was successfully submitted and the project awarded in August 2021 - the first community college LSAMP alliance in California. The C6 B2B Alliance focuses on increasing the success rates of URM students in STEM courses, as well increasing the number of URM students transferring to universities and thriving in STEM majors.


Last Modified: 03/31/2022
Modified by: Dominic J Dal Bello

Louis Stokes Pre-Alliance Planning Project:
C6: California Central Coast Community College Collaborative
NSF Award No. 1817508

Eight California community colleges were supported by a National Science Foundation Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (NSF LSAMP) Pre-Alliance planning grant to create the California Central Coast Community College Collaborative (C6). The goals of the C6 Pre-Alliance planning grant included:

 Bringing together faculty, staff, and administration of three community colleges in Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo Counties, and expanding that alliance to include neighboring community colleges, south from Ventura County northward to Santa Cruz County.
Assessing URM student needs via student surveys
Connecting and consulting with the University of California (UC) LSAMP Alliance, the California State University (CSU) LSAMP Alliance, other LSAMP and existing STEM support programs to strengthen cooperation and articulation, as well as to investigate possible joint activities to facilitate student transfer and transition
Conducting a literature review, sharing existing support frame works across institutions, attending conferences, and visiting successful LSAMP programs in the state and nation to learn best practices
Coordinating discussions across campus institutional research departments that identify transfer pathway barriers
Writing and submitting a full LSAMP grant proposal at the end of the planning period


An initial kick-off meeting was attended by over 30 faculty, staff and administrators from ten community colleges (eventually eight colleges were able to participate in the project). COVID would soon make in-person meetings impossible, but Zoom was leveraged, allowing the C6 alliance members to meet monthly during the research and development stages of the proposal, and bi-weekly during the writing stages. The ultimate product of the pre-alliance planning grant - a LSAMP B2B proposal - was successfully submitted and the project awarded in August 2021 - the first community college LSAMP alliance in California.
